title: Apprentice Doctor Faces Tribunal Over Offensive Social Media Posts
summary: Dr. Asif Munaf, a former contestant on the 2024 edition of The Apprentice, is facing a medical tribunal for posting a series of offensive content on social media. The General Medical Council (GMC) alleges that between October 2023 and July 2025, he shared antisemitic posts, including Holocaust denial, conspiracy theories, and imagery equating Jews with Nazism, such as a flag with the Star of David above a swastika. Additionally, he reposted racist comments using a derogatory slur against boxer Floyd Mayweather and expressed sexist views by arguing for gender restrictions in certain professions and criticizing female empowerment. Munaf, who did not attend the tribunal and is unrepresented, previously denied the antisemitic nature of the posts, claiming they were not befitting of an educated person and made in emotional heat. The GMC also accuses him of misconduct for walking out of a locum placement at a hospital without notice in January 2024 and providing a sick note to a patient while suspended in November 2024. The hearing continues to assess these allegations and potential disciplinary actions.

background_read: This article discusses a serious case involving a doctor's misconduct through social media posts and professional actions. In the UK, doctors are regulated by the General Medical Council (GMC), which sets standards for ethical behavior. Antisemitism refers to hostility toward Jewish people, and Holocaust denial is a form of this that ignores historical facts. Social media platforms allow rapid sharing of content, but posts can have real-world consequences, especially for public figures like TV contestants. Medical tribunals are legal processes to investigate allegations against healthcare professionals, ensuring public safety and trust. Understanding these concepts helps in evaluating the impact of online behavior and professional responsibilities.
